vectorData.altText: Identify the zone of the adrenal cortex.

That's right! The cells of the zona reticularis are smaller than those in other zones of the adrenal cortex, and are arranged in anastomosing networks. there is an abrupt transition to the adrenal medulla seen in the lower part of this image.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
H10   Zones of the Adrenal Cortex

The zona glomerulosa (ZG) consists of knots of cells surrounding fenestrated capillary beds. Cells here respond to circulating angiotensin II and elevated plasma K+ to produce mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone promotes the retention of Na+ and water, at the expense of K+, in the kidney.

The largest zone of the adrenal cortex is the zona fasciculata. Cells here are arranged in elongated cords (fascicles) running parallel to fenestrated sinusoidal capillary beds. These cells respond to ACTH from the anterior pituitary to produce glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol. Amongst other effects, cortisol stimulates gluconeogenesis in many tissues and glycogen synthesis in the liver.

The deepest zone of the adrenal cortex is the zona reticularis. Cells here form an anastomosing network, intimately associated with sinusoidal capillaries. Cells here also respond to ACTH, but their main product is weak androgens, primarily dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), which in both men and women is converted to testosterone.
ZR  Inner zone (7^%^), one-cell wide anastomosing rows. Cells have a central nucleus eosinophilic or pink cytoplasm, secrete weak androgens.
